thread.title: Kakadu Bird Week from October 14-21 reveals feathered delight of a Top End region home to a third of Australia’s bird species | DailyTelegraph
thread.title_full: Kakadu Bird Week from October 14-21 reveals feathered delight of a Top End region home to a third of Australia’s bird species | DailyTelegraph

author: Briar Jensen
title: Kakadu Bird Week from October 14-21 reveals feathered delight of a Top End region home to a third of Australia’s bird species | DailyTelegraph
text:
FEATHERY bottoms bob in the water like black and white marker buoys as magpie geese flip upside down, straining their necks to reach bulbs at the bottom of the billabong.
Nearby, an elegant white egret saunters through the water like a slinky model in teetering stilettos, pausing statuesquely, as if for the paparazzi.
Rows of whistling ducks stand headless on one leg, necks folded backwards, beaks buried between their wings resting in the midday sun.
A thick mat of water lilies, or red lotus, carpets the billabong, the huge elephant-ear-sized leaves held above the water like satellite dishes catching the sunlight. Thrusting up between and towering above are blushing pink blooms, adding lollipops of colour to the myriad shades of green.
Branches of a tree bow under the weight of little pied cormorants, their black and white attire giving rise to their moniker as penguins of the Top End.
Kakadu National Park, in Australia’s Northern Territory, is home to around 290 bird species, about one-third of Australia’s total. Mamukala Wetlands, part of the South Alligator River flood plain and the first major stop on the Arnhem Highway from Darwin, is visited by an estimated 60 species of water birds, some on a seasonal basis and from as far away as the sub-Arctic.
Other Stories ‘It’s hard to accept... the cruelty on their bodies’ News 0 comments Who were Playboy’s Aussie stars? Sydney Confidential 0 comments Terror threats: ‘Thousands will die’ National Chloe: I’m not used to the fame Sydney Confidential 0 comments Knights sign half, Raiders re-sign centre Nrl 0 comments Esquire names the sexiest woman alive Books 0 comments Plumed whistling ducks on Yellow Water Billabong, Kakadu. Picture: Kakadu Tourism Towards the end of the dry season, as the wetlands shrink, they provide home to thousands of magpie geese, which were once an important food source for the local Bininj people. The geese rummage for water chestnuts buried in the mud at the base of spike-rushes, hence their bottoms-up profile as I watch from a bird hide.
It’s a similar scene at Anbangbang billabong, where we picnic under a shady paperbark tree listening to the high pitched whistles of green pygmy geese. Signs warn not to get too close to the water due to the possibility of crocodiles, so we take the circular walk through the fringing paperbark swamp, dry at this time of year.
A flash of orange darting between the trees brings my first glimpse of a rainbow bee-eater, a tiny bird which lives up to its colourful name and is Australia’s only bee-eater. Equally small and jauntily flicking fanned-tails are spritely willie wagtails.
Raucous squawking in the upper branches of a paperbark turns out to be a flock of red-tailed black cockatoos.
I’m no twitcher – a serious birdwatcher – and I haven’t come to Kakadu for the bird life, but the sheer number and variety of birds is beguiling.
A majestic jabiru goes fishing. Picture: iStock On a Yellow Water’s sunset cruise I lose count of the number of birds we see, along with lazing crocodiles, grazing water buffalo and brumbies.
It’s here I see my first Jesus bird, or comb-crested jacana, picking its way across lotus leaves. Its common name derives from its ability to “walk on water”, or at least lily pads, thanks to enormous splayed feet, which are almost the same length as its legs.
Our enthusiastic guide points out a tiny azure kingfisher, dazzling in topcoat of violet blue over an orange undershirt. Scanning for much larger fish is a pair of white-bellied sea eagles, Australia’s second largest bird of prey, with a wingspan in excess of 2 metres.
Reflections lengthen on the water; snake-necked darters outstretch wings to dry; glossy ibis flash iridescent-green plumage; and majestic jabiru and brolgas stalk through the reeds.
As smoke from burn-offs tinges the air and the sinking sun silhouettes pandanus against an orange sky, magpie geese take to the air. It’s estimated more than three million of them call Kakadu home. Watching wave after V-shaped wave crowd the sky at twilight is truly a spectacle.
So seductive is Yellow Water, we come back for a sunrise cruise, and the transformation is magical. Mist swirls over the water as geese return across a pink-tinged sky. Every few metres a croc sashays through the water.
Elegant white egrets are the supermodels of the wetlands. Picture: iStock But again it’s the birds that excite – nankeen night herons, a pheasant coucal and the elusive little kingfisher. I think I feel a twitch coming on.
TIPS
● Take binoculars to enhance your viewing of distant birds.
● Download the Kakadu Bird App which includes more than 50 birds by region.
● Read up. Kakadu National Park by Paul Arnold is a photographic souvenir that includes 80 bird species, $10; Birds of the Top End by Malcolm Arnold is a pocket-sized reference aimed at novice birdwatchers, $5;
A Natural History and Field Guide to Australia’s Top End by Lucas, Morris, van Oosterzee & Preece gives more detail on the geology, flora and fauna, $32.95. All books available from Warradjan Cultural Centre, Cooinda.
The writer travelled with the assistance of Kakadu Tourism and Tourism NT.
GO2
KAKADU
BIRD WEEK
See Kakadu’s diverse birdlife across wetlands, woodlands and sandstone escarpments during Bird Week from October 14-21. Activities include talks, guided walks and special cruises with events for experienced and novice twitchers. There’s a mini Twitchathon, the opportunity to take part in scientific monitoring surveys and a photographic competition on the park’s Facebook page ( facebook.com/kakadunationalpark ).
See parksaustralia.gov.au/kakadu/do/bird-week.html
GETTING THERE
Kakadu is easily accessible by car from Darwin (133km) or Katherine (149km) but distances between sites in the park can be long.
STAYING THERE
Cooinda Lodge, next to Yellow Water billabong, has a Bird Week Stay & Save package, with 20 per cent discount off two nights or more, with rates starting from $144 a night. Powered camping sites at Cooinda Campground start from $46 a night. Rates at the Mercure Crocodile Hotel in Jabiru start from $179.
